author: CannaVestments
body:
As others have pointed out, there are some huge flaws and unfound assumptions in your investing premise:

1. Federal legalization, especially as outlined by Biden, certainly does not mean open border cannabis trade with Canada, even it was for just medical. One of the primary foundations of the US cannabis industry is the wealth of jobs and tax revenue it creates here locally... why would Biden/Trump or any state legislature create a federal legalization framework that would hand over the market to Canadian imports??
2. Given (1), the primary methods LPs will then enter the US market is buying out licenses or partnering with existing operators (as we have seen CGC attempt to do already). CGC/CRON and maybe APH are the only ones with enough capital to make a significant entry and they will be paying top dollar to do so as license valuations will shoot through the roof upon federal legalization. The majority of LPs are just attempting to stay afloat at this point given cash burn rates... not sure how you envision them buying out US operators with far better financials.
3. The idea that hemp operations will be an avenue to future THC licensing is also unproven at this point. It could, but no states have allowed this to-date so investing based on that thesis would be quite the gamble.

As such, the idea of investing in LPs on the potential that they might pay top dollar for future US licenses seems extremely inefficient, especially considering the wealth of new capital that would enter the market at the same time. Owning well-run US operators who would be attractive buy-out targets seems like a far better method of capitalizing on US legalization. The OTC/CSE critique is nonsense imo- under the scenario you outline, those US operators would be allowed to uplist to the higher exchanges anyway. Not to mention, the top MSO CSE stocks have been outperforming LPs on larger exchanges for some time now.

author: ps3alltheway
body:
The only real thing I can say is diversify your portfolio. I don't think you will lose holding Aphria, but I don't think this is a 5 bagger/10 bagger like I used to think. 
A few provinces fucked up the roll out so Aphria has not reached it'a full potential yet, so for that reason I don't worry about selling at loss since it's one of the best managed mj companies (sigh). But weed as a cap just like booze has one.  +/- 40 million habitants in Canada, not everyone consumes cannabis. I remember all theses posts about how millenials give up alcohol for cannabis and this is truly not true. People that like to drink and hang out will keep drinking, doesn't matter if they are millenials or not, people that want to chill will keep smoking. Legalization Didn't contribute in creating many more users, all the people that smoked are still smoking and I don't know that many people that dropped booze for weed, yes there are a few but not as much people think. The only difference is instead of buying weed from Little joe or buymyweedonline people go to retail shops. So this said, Aphria IMO as more room to grow, but do I think this is a 10b company in the future? Look at what is happening in the world, by the time Europe and LATAM fully legalizes Aph will have the operations overseas shut down to focus on cost control here in Canada IMO. Covid's colleteral damage on the economy has not even started yet

author: GuyOnTheCouch420
body:
I think there’s more of a spread between top Canadian companies and the rest than Us companies.  The top 5 Canadian companies raised an insane amount of capital a few years ago that is just light years beyond what the Us companies did. Add up CGC, CRON, ACB, APH, TLRY...it’s a ton. After that there is a pretty big drop off. But agree their revenues don’t compare. 

The Us, you still have some top ones. But the spread between CURA, TRuL, GTi from a capital raising perspective isn’t as huge compared to MMEN, Cresco, Harvest, IaN, etc. though Cura does seem to be in a different class from a dollars raised view. 

So all that being said, US companies overall are far behind CDN even a few years ago dollars raised (CDN companies haven’t raise nearly as much last year and half as they did before). But when you take out CDN outliers (especially CGC/CRON), I think you’re right as far as where they are positioned.
